Namespacing Swift code with nested¬†types

While Swift does not yet feature a dedicated namespace keyword, it does support nesting types within others. Let‚Äôs take a look at how using such nested types can help us improve the structure of our code.

Many Swift developers are used to do namespacing through including structural levels in the actual name of a type‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääusing names like PostTextFormatterOption (an Option for a Text Formatter used to format Posts). This is probably because this was pretty much the only way to do sort of a ‚Äúpoor man‚Äôs namespacing‚Äù in Objective-C & C, and like many other conventions it has carried over to Swift.

Let‚Äôs use the type mentioned above as an example, and take a look at the implementations of Post, PostTextFormatter & PostTextFormatterOption:

Now let‚Äôs take a look at how the above types change if we instead structure them as nested types inside of Post:

One big advantage of the nested types approach is that we can now clearly see the structure and relationship between our types just by taking a quick look at our code. We have also reduced the verbosity in our initializer, making it shorter and easier to read (the options argument is now simply of type Set<Option> instead of Set<PostTextFormatterOption>).

We now also get a clear sense of hierarchy at the call site‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääeverything related to a Post is now neatly structured under the Post. namespace. Here‚Äôs what formatting a post‚Äôs text looks like:

However, using nested types like above also has a pretty significant downside. The code is kind of ‚Äúbackwards‚Äù vertically, where the actual content of the parent type gets pushed all the way down to the bottom. So let‚Äôs try to fix that by flipping our structure‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämoving our nested types down to the bottom, instead of having them at the top (we also throw in some MARKs, for good measure).

Whether you prefer the nested types to be on the top or bottom is definetly going to be a personal preference. I kind of like how it lets me keep the actual content of the parent type at the top‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhile still giving the code the hierarchical benefits of nested types.

However, like with many things in Swift, it turns out there‚Äôs a couple of more ways to implement namespacing & nested types.

Nested types in extensions

One option is to use extensions to implement your nested types. This gives you a clearer separation between the types, while still retaining the hierarchy both in the implementation and at the call site.

Here‚Äôs what that looks like for our types:

Using typealiases

You can also add typealiases to the original code (that didn‚Äôt use nested types) to achieve a nested type-ish behavior. While this doesn‚Äôt give you the same level of hierarchy in the implementation, it does help reduce the verbosity‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand it also provides the same benefits at the call site as when using nested types.

Here‚Äôs what that option looks like:

Conclusion

Using nested types can help you create a really nice structure & hierarchies in your code, to help make it clearer what the relationships are between your various types‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääboth in the implementation and at the call site.

However, depending on what technique you choose to implement them, you may face other challenges and side effects‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääso I think picking the technique depending on the situation becomes really important, in order to end up with a net win.

What do you think? Which one of the above techniques to you prefer for namespacing your code? Or have you found another one? Let me know, along with any questions or comments, on Twitter @johnsundell.

(Oh, and by the way, as of Swift 3.1 nested types can also be used inside generics! üéâ¬†‚Ä¶but more on that in an upcoming post üòâ)
